1.0    OVERVIEW



Installation Background



Scott Air Force Base (SAFB) is located in St. Clair County, in the southwest portion of Illinois. To the northeast of the base is the community of Lebanon, to the southeast is Mascoutah, to the west are Belleville and Shiloh, and to the northwest is O'Fallon. MidAmerica Airport lies adjacent to the base to the north and east, and the remaining areas surrounding the base consists of some of the finest farmland within the state. The City of St. Louis is located only 20 miles to the west. Springfield, the capital of Illinois, is just over 100 miles north of the installation.



The total SAFB community is made up of more than 30,900 military and civilian personnel and their families living on and off base. SAFB employs nearly 13,000 airmen and civilians. In addition, there are also about 8,500 military retirees that the base serves.



The 375 Air Mobility Wing is the host unit at SAFB. 



SAFB is also the home of other groups that include the United States Transportation Command, Air Mobility Command, Illinois Air National Guard 126 AW and the Air Force Reserve 932 Aeromedical Airlift Wing. Major groups under the 375 AW include the 375 Operations Group, 375 Logistics Group, 375 Support Group, and the 375 Medical Group.



The 375 AW is host to a number of on- and off-base tenant units. These organizations represent a variety of critical Department of Defense (DOD) activities. 



There are a more than 1,400 military family housing units at SAFB. Of these units, including multi-unit dormitory style buildings and family housing. 



Risk Management Background



A Risk Management Program (RMP) has been implemented at Scott AFB for the reduction of accidental releases of hazardous materials. The RMP summarizes the management, administrative, procedural, and technological controls that work together to minimize the risk to the community from hazardous chemical releases. 3.0    HAZARD (OFF-SITE ANALYSIS)



Worst-Case Release Scenario Analysis



This section summarizes the worst-case release scenario and public receptors associated with the chlorine process at the WWTP. Chlorine is stored at the WWTP near the southeast corner of the base property. Although the WWTP is located away from a majority of the base population, there are several public access areas nearby which would be of concern during a worst case scenario.



The RMP regulations define a worst-case release scenario or circle of concern as the release of the largest quantity of a regulated substance from a vessel or process line failure that results in the greatest distance to an endpoint. The worst case release scenario for toxic gases is assumed to be the total release of the single largest container in the process over a 10-minute duration. The worst case release scenario for the WWTP chlorine storage at Scott AFB would involve the failure of a chlorine cylinder containing 2,000 lbs. of chlorine. The chlorine would be released as a gas, and would form a vapor cloud that would travel in a downwind direction. If 2,000 lbs of chlorine gas were released over a 10-minute duration the endpoint would be 1.3 miles from the site of chlorine storage. 



A chlorine gas release from the chlorine storage area at the WWTP would affect public receptors during a worst-case release scenario. A public receptor is defined as "off-site residences, institutions (e.g., schools, hospitals) industrial, commercial, and office buildings, parks, or recreational areas inhabited or occupied by the public at any time without restri

ction by the stationary source where members of the public could be exposed to toxic concentrations, radiant heat, or overpressure, as a result of an accidental release" (40 CFR 68.3). For the purposes of this RMP, any building or area on Base where public access is allowed on an unrestricted basis was considered a public receptor. Public receptors at Scott AFB would include residences, recreational areas and a school. 



RMP regulations require an estimate of the residential population within the circle of concern for the worst-case scenario.  For chlorine, approximately 41,000 persons could be impacted.



Alternative Release Scenario Analysis (ARS)



An ARS event is more probable than a worst-case scenario. The RMP Guidance for Wastewater Treatment Plants provides a standard table for an unmitigated release rate. The WWTP chlorine storage area is enclosed by a permanent structure. The release of a liquefied gas from a 1-ton cylinder (under 98.5 psig) due to a sheered valve or line would result in a release rate of 10 lbs/min over a 30-minute period. The release would travel a distance of 0.2 miles and would reach the base jogging trail a nearby playground.



4.0    PROGRAM LEVEL DETERMINATION



The EPA outlines three program levels for the RMP Prevention Program. Scott AFB's chlorine storage and usage at the WWTP qualifies as a Program Level 2 Prevention Program under Illinois EPA and the OSHA PSM rule (29 CFR 1910.119) with a threshold of 1,500 lbs.



Scott AFB also stores large amounts of propane.  The amount of propane stored at the Fire Training Facility does not exceed the 67,000-lbs threshold and the RMP rule does not apply to this source. 



5.0    PREVENTION PROGRAM



Scott AFB currently maintains a Prevention Program for this Program Level 2 process (chlorine) contained in a separate document entitled "Accident Prevention and Process Safety Management Program." This prevention program ensures that:



Process safety information is provided to all employ

ees

Hazard analyses are completed every five years

Written operating procedures are followed by employees and kept up-to-date.

Initial and refresher training is provided to all employees

Pre-startup safety reviews are conducted

Mechanical integrity assurance program is in place

Hot work is permitted

Incidents are investigated



6.0    EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



In addition to the prevention program, Scott AFB maintains a Spill Prevention Control and Countermeasure Plan (SPCC) to mitigate the effects of accidental releases should they occur. The Scott AFB Fire Department is staffed 24 hours per day, 365 days per year.



7.0    FIVE-YEAR HISTORY



Scott AFB has not experienced an accidental release of chlorine during the past five years. Scott AFB reports all releases of hazardous chemicals, regardless of , to local and state regulatory agencies.



8.0    PLANNED CHANGES TO ELIMINATE CHLORINE STORAGE/USE



Scott AFB currently employs a safety checklist when changing chlorine gas cylinders at the WWTP. 



In an effort to eliminate RMP requirements and reduce risk of chlorine release, Scott AFB conducted a study to determine alternatives to chlorine disinfection at the WWTP. Three alternatives were developed with a focus on eliminating chlorine storage: (1) changing chlorine storage cylinder  to reduce storage capacity to under the 1,500-lbs threshold, (2) utilize a substitute disinfection chemical and (3) utilize a non-chemical disinfection technology. 



Prudent Technologies interviewed WWTP personnel to identify any solutions to reducing chlorine storage cylinder .



Substitute chemicals would require infrastructure improvements. Such chemicals included ozone, peroxone and others.



The preferred cost-effective solution to eliminate chlorine use at the WWTP is the implementation of ultra-violet (UV) disinfection technology. If this alternative were implemented, Scott AFB would no longer be subject to RMP regulatory requirements.



Scott AFB has no future p

lans to introduce additional chemicals that would require sustainment of a RMP.



9.0    RMP MANAGEMENT PLAN



A Risk Management Team of responsible parties is in place and includes first responders, operators, ground safety, environmental and occupational health specialists at Scott AFB. The primary point of contact for this plan is the Air Program Manager within the Environmental Section of 375 CES.



The Team is responsible for implementing, overseeing and updating the RMP. Updates will be conducted whenever:



* A newly regulated substance is first listed by the EPA,

* A regulated substance is above its threshold for the first time,

* A revised PHA, hazard review or consequence analysis due to a changed process,

* Program Level changes,

* The facility is no longer subject to RMP requirements (de-registration).



The RMP Management Team is responsible for meeting RMP requirements until process use and storage of regulated amounts of chlorine is discontinued at the WWTP.
